text: As a boy in UsulutÃ¡n in eastern El Salvador, Juan Romagosa grew up knowing that one day he would become either a doctor or a priest.
The church called first with the casual force of inevitability.

The signs of a future life in the Catholic ministry were everywhere, starting on the street where he lived in a Spanish colonial house with his parents, eight siblings, grandparents, an aunt, and an uncle.
It was just around the corner from the city's main church, a simple but imposing building with two towers and a broad front staircase.
Early each morning, the family attended mass.
On Sundays at the house of Juan's great-grandparents, the bishop would often visit for lunch.
He was a stiff, corpulent man who dressed in a flowing white robe.
Jewelry covered his hands and neck.
The adults used to summon Juan and the other children to kneel before him and kiss one of his rings.
The whole family was muy beata, neighbors used to say.
They were church folks, pious in the extreme.
